description: An ospfVirtIfStateChange trap signifies that there
has been a change in the state of an OSPF virtual
interface.
This trap should be generated when the interface
state regresses (e.g., goes from Point-to-Point to Down)
or progresses to a terminal state
(i.e., Point-to-Point).

Summary.eval: ($v4 == 1) ? 'OSPF Virtual-Interface State - {Down} with IfAreaID - {$v2} and Virtual-IfNeighbor - {$v3}' : (($v4 == 4) ? 'OSPF Virtual-Interface State - {Point-to-Point} with IfAreaID - {$v2} and Virtual-IfNeighbor - {$v3}' : 'OSPF Virtual-Interface State - {Unknown} with IfAreaId - {$v2} and Virtual-IfNeighbor - {$v3}')

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfVirtIfStateChange OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId a 1.1.1.1 OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtIfAreaId a 2.2.2.2 OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtIfNeighbor a 3.3.3.3 OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtIfState i 1

description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the
router in the Autonomous System.
By convention, to ensure uniqueness, this
should default to the value of one of the
router's IP interface addresses.
This object is persistent and when written
the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId

description: The transit area that the virtual link
traverses. By definition, this is not 0.0.0.0.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtIfAreaId

description: The Router ID of the virtual neighbor.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtIfNeighbor

description: OSPF virtual interface states.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtIfState

description: An ospfNbrStateChange trap signifies that
there has been a change in the state of a
non-virtual OSPF neighbor. This trap should be
generated when the neighbor state regresses
(e.g., goes from Attempt or Full to 1-Way or
Down) or progresses to a terminal state (e.g.
2-Way or Full). When an neighbor transitions
from or to Full on non-broadcast multi-access
and broadcast networks, the trap should be
generated by the designated router. A designated
router transitioning to Down will be noted by
ospfIfStateChange.

Summary.eval: ($v2 eq '0.0.0.0') ? 'OSPF Neighbor State - {$v5} with Neighbor-SourceIPAddress - {$v2}, IfIndex - {$v3} and Neighbor-Router - {$v4}' : (($v2 ne '0.0.0.0') ? 'OSPF Neighbor State - {$v5} with Neighbor-SourceIPAddress - {$v2} and Neighbor-Router - {$v4}' : 'OSPF Neighbor State - {Unknown} with Neighbor-SourceIPAddress - {$v2}, IfIndex - {$v3} and Neighbor-Router - {$v4}')

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfNbrStateChange OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId a 1.1.1.1 OSPF-MIB::ospfNbrIpAddr a 2.2.2.2 OSPF-MIB::ospfNbrAddressLessIndex i 9999 OSPF-MIB::ospfNbrRtrId a 3.3.3.3 OSPF-MIB::ospfNbrState i 5

description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the
router in the Autonomous System.
By convention, to ensure uniqueness, this
should default to the value of one of the
router's IP interface addresses.
This object is persistent and when written
the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId

description: The IP address this neighbor is using in its
IP source address. Note that, on addressless
links, this will not be 0.0.0.0 but the
address of another of the neighbor's interfaces.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfNbrIpAddr

description: On an interface having an IP address, zero.
On addressless interfaces, the corresponding
value of ifIndex in the Internet Standard MIB.
On row creation, this can be derived from the
instance.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfNbrAddressLessIndex

description: A 32-bit integer (represented as a type
IpAddress) uniquely identifying the neighboring
router in the Autonomous System.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfNbrRtrId

description: The state of the relationship with this neighbor.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfNbrState

description: An ospfVirtNbrStateChange trap signifies that there
has been a change in the state of an OSPF virtual
neighbor. This trap should be generated
when the neighbor state regresses (e.g., goes
from Attempt or Full to 1-Way or Down) or
progresses to a terminal state (e.g., Full).

Summary.eval: ($v4 == 1) ? 'OSPF Neighbor-Relationship-State - {Down}, Neighbor-Area - {$v2} and Virtual-Neighbor-Router - {$v3}' : (($v4 == 2) ? 'OSPF Neighbor-Relationship-State - {Attempt}, Neighbor-Area - {$v2} and Virtual-Neighbor- {$v3}' : (($v4 == 3) ? 'OSPF Neighbor-Relationship-State - {Init}, Neighbor-Area - {$v2} and Virtual-Neighbor-Router - {$v3}' : (($v4 == 4) ? 'OSPF Neighbor-Relationship-State - {2-way}, Neighbor-Area - {$v2} and Virtual-Neighbor-Router - {$v3}' : (($v4 == 5) ? 'OSPF Neighbor-Relationship-State  - {ExchangeStart}, Neighbor-Area - {$v2} and Virtual-Neighbor-Router - {$v3}' : (($v4 == 6) ? 'OSPF Neighbor Exchange, Area: $v2 and Virtual Neighbor $v3' : (($v4 == 7) ? 'OSPF Neighbor-Relationship-State Loading, Neighbor-Area: $v2 and Virtual-Neighbor-Router - {$v3}' : (($v4 == 8) ? 'OSPF Neighbor-Relastionship-State - {Full}, Neighbor-Area - {$v2} and Virtual-Neighbor-Router - {$v3}' : 'OSPF Neighbor-Relationship-State - {Unknown}, Neighbor-Area - {$v2} and Virtual-Neighbor-Router - {$v3}')))))))

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfVirtNbrStateChange OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId a 1.1.1.1 OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtNbrArea a 2.2.2.2 OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtNbrRtrId a 3.3.3.3 OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtNbrState i 1

description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the
router in the Autonomous System.
By convention, to ensure uniqueness, this
should default to the value of one of the
router's IP interface addresses.
This object is persistent and when written
the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId

description: The Transit Area Identifier.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtNbrArea

description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the
neighboring router in the Autonomous System.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtNbrRtrId

description: The state of the virtual neighbor relationship.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtNbrState

description: An ospfIfConfigError trap signifies that a
packet has been received on a non-virtual
interface from a router whose configuration
parameters conflict with this router's
configuration parameters. Note that the event
optionMismatch should cause a trap only if it
prevents an adjacency from forming.

Summary.eval: ($v3 == 0) ? 'OSPFInterfaceConfigError:PacketType - {$v6}, ConfigErrorType - {$v5} and InterfaceIPAddress - {$v2}' : 'OSPFInterfaceConfigError:PacketType - {$v6}, ConfigErrorType - {$v5}, InterfaceIPAddress - {$v2} and NoIpInterfaceIfIndex - {$v3}'

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfIfConfigError OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId a 127.0.0.1 OSPF-MIB::ospfIfIpAddress a 127.0.0.1 OSPF-MIB::ospfAddressLessIf i 9999 OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfPacketSrc a 127.0.0.1 OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfConfigErrorType i 1 OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfPacketType i 1

description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the
router in the Autonomous System.
By convention, to ensure uniqueness, this
should default to the value of one of the
router's IP interface addresses.
This object is persistent and when written
the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId

description: The IP address of this OSPF interface.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfIfIpAddress

description: For the purpose of easing the instancing of
addressed and addressless interfaces; this
variable takes the value 0 on interfaces with
IP addresses and the corresponding value of
ifIndex for interfaces having no IP address.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfAddressLessIf

description: The IP address of an inbound packet that cannot
be identified by a neighbor instance. When
the last value of a trap using this object is
needed, but no traps of that type have been sent
this value pertaining to this object should
be returned as 0.0.0.0.
variables.name: OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfPacketSrc

description: Potential types of configuration conflicts.
Used by the ospfConfigError and
ospfConfigVirtError traps. When the last value
of a trap using this object is needed, but no
traps of that type have been sent, this value
pertaining to this object should be returned as
noError.
variables.name: OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfConfigErrorType

description: OSPF packet types. When the last value of a trap
using this object is needed, but no traps of
that type have been sent, this value pertaining
to this object should be returned as nullPacket.
variables.name: OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfPacketType

description: An ospfVirtIfConfigError trap signifies that a
packet has been received on a virtual interface
from a router whose configuration parameters
conflict with this router's configuration
parameters. Note that the event optionMismatch
should cause a trap only if it prevents an
adjacency from forming.
objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfVirtIfConfigError OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId a 127.0.0.1 OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtIfAreaId a 127.0.0.1 OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtIfNeighbor a 127.0.0.1 OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfConfigErrorType i 1 OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfPacketType i 1

router's IP interface addresses.

description: The Router ID of the virtual neighbor.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtIfNeighbor

variables.name: OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfPacketType

description: An ospfIfAuthFailure trap signifies that a
packet has been received on a non-virtual
interface from a router whose authentication key
or authentication type conflicts with this
router's authentication key or authentication
type.

Summary.eval: ($v3 == 0) ? 'ospfIfAuthFailure:PacketType - {$v6}, ConfigErrorType - {$v5} and InterfaceIPAddress - {$v2}' : 'ospfIfAuthFailure:PacketType - {$v6}, ConfigErrorType - {$v5}, InterfaceIPAddress - {$v2} and NoIpAddress-InterfaceIfIndex - {$v3}'

description: An ospfIfRxBadPacket trap signifies that an
OSPF packet has been received on a non-virtual
interface that cannot be parsed.

Summary.eval: ($v3 == 0) ? 'ospfIfRxBadPacket: Received PacketType - {$v5}, Cannot Be Parsed InterfaceIPAddress - {$v2}' : 'ospfIfRxBadPacket: Received PacketType - {$v5}, Cannot Be Parsed NoIpAddress-InterfaceIfIndex - {$v3}'

packet has been received on a virtual interface
that cannot be parsed.

event.Summary: ospfVirtIfRxBadPacket:  Received Bad Packet of PacketType - {$v4}, Cannot Be Parsed, AreaId - {$v2} and Virtual-NeighborIfEntry - {$v3}

router in the Autonomous System.

should default to the value of one of the
router's IP interface addresses.

traverses. By definition, this is not 0.0.0.0.

description: An ospfTxRetransmit trap signifies than an
OSPF packet has been retransmitted on a
non-virtual interface. All packets that may be
retransmitted are associated with an LSDB entry.
The LS type, LS ID, and Router ID are used to
identify the LSDB entry.

Summary.eval: ($v3 == 0) ? 'ospfTxRetransmit: PacketType - {$v5} Retransmitted to Neighbor-Router - {$v4} and IpAddress-Interface - {$v2}' : 'ospfTxRetransmit: PacketType - {$v5} Retransmitted to Neighbor-Router - {$v4} and  NoIpAddress-InterfaceIfIndex - {$v3}'

description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the
router in the Autonomous System.
By convention, to ensure uniqueness, this
should default to the value of one of the
router's IP interface addresses.
This object is persistent and when written
the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId

description: The IP address of this OSPF interface.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfIfIpAddress

description: For the purpose of easing the instancing of
addressed and addressless interfaces; this
variable takes the value 0 on interfaces with
IP addresses and the corresponding value of
ifIndex for interfaces having no IP address.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfAddressLessIf

description: A 32-bit integer (represented as a type
IpAddress) uniquely identifying the neighboring
router in the Autonomous System.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfNbrRtrId

description: OSPF packet types. When the last value of a trap
using this object is needed, but no traps of
that type have been sent, this value pertaining
to this object should be returned as nullPacket.
variables.name: OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfPacketType

description: The type of the link state advertisement.
Each link state type has a separate advertisement
format.
Note: External link state advertisements are permitted
for backward compatibility, but should be displayed
in the ospfAsLsdbTable rather than here.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfLsdbType

description: The Link State ID is an LS Type Specific field
containing either a Router ID or an IP address;
it identifies the piece of the routing domain
that is being described by the advertisement.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfLsdbLsid

description: The 32-bit number that uniquely identifies the
originating router in the Autonomous System.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfLsdbRouterId

description: An ospfVirtIfTxRetransmit trap signifies than an
OSPF packet has been retransmitted on a virtual
interface. All packets that may be retransmitted
are associated with an LSDB entry. The LS
type, LS ID, and Router ID are used to identify
the LSDB entry.

event.Summary: ospfVirtIfTxRetransmit: {$v4} PacketType Retransmitted to AreaID - {$v2} and Virtual-NeighborRouterID - {$v3}

variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfLsdbLsid

description: The 32-bit number that uniquely identifies the
originating router in the Autonomous System.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfLsdbRouterId

description: An ospfOriginateLsa trap signifies that a new
LSA has been originated by this router. This
trap should not be invoked for simple refreshes
of LSAs (which happens every 30 minutes), but
instead will only be invoked when an LSA is
(re)originated due to a topology change.
Additionally, this trap does not include LSAs that
are being flushed because they have reached
MaxAge.

event.Summary: New LSA Originated: AreaID - {$v2}, LSAType - {$v3}, LSID - {$v4}, LSARouterID - {$v5}

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfOriginateLsa OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId a 127.0.0.1 OSPF-MIB::ospfLsdbAreaId a 1.1.1.1 OSPF-MIB::ospfLsdbType i 1 OSPF-MIB::ospfLsdbLsid a 2.2.2.2 OSPF-MIB::ospfLsdbRouterId a 3.3.3.3

description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the
router in the Autonomous System.

router's IP interface addresses.
This object is persistent and when written
the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.

description: The 32-bit identifier of the area from which
the LSA was received.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfLsdbAreaId

description: The type of the link state advertisement.
Each link state type has a separate advertisement
format.

in the ospfAsLsdbTable rather than here.

description: The Link State ID is an LS Type Specific field
containing either a Router ID or an IP address;

variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfLsdbLsid

description: The 32-bit number that uniquely identifies the
originating router in the Autonomous System.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfLsdbRouterId

description: An ospfMaxAgeLsa trap signifies that one of
the LSAs in the router's link state database has
aged to MaxAge.

event.Summary: LSA Aged to MaxAge: AreaID - {$v2}, LSAType - {$v3}, LSID - {$v4}, LSA-Router - {$v5}

variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId

description: The 32-bit identifier of the area from which
the LSA was received.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfLsdbAreaId

description: The type of the link state advertisement.
Each link state type has a separate advertisement
format.
Note: External link state advertisements are permitted
for backward compatibility, but should be displayed
in the ospfAsLsdbTable rather than here.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfLsdbType

description: The Link State ID is an LS Type Specific field
containing either a Router ID or an IP address;
it identifies the piece of the routing domain
that is being described by the advertisement.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfLsdbLsid

description: The 32-bit number that uniquely identifies the
originating router in the Autonomous System.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfLsdbRouterId

description: An ospfLsdbOverflow trap signifies that the
number of LSAs in the router's link state
database has exceeded ospfExtLsdbLimit.
objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfLsdbOverflow OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId a 127.0.0.1 OSPF-MIB::ospfExtLsdbLimit i 9999

description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the
router in the Autonomous System.
By convention, to ensure uniqueness, this
should default to the value of one of the
router's IP interface addresses.
This object is persistent and when written
the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId

description: The maximum number of non-default
AS-external LSAs entries that can be stored in the
link state database. If the value is -1, then
there is no limit.
When the number of non-default AS-external LSAs
in a router's link state database reaches
ospfExtLsdbLimit, the router enters
overflow state. The router never holds more than
ospfExtLsdbLimit non-default AS-external LSAs
in its database. OspfExtLsdbLimit MUST be set
identically in all routers attached to the OSPF
backbone and/or any regular OSPF area (i.e.
OSPF stub areas and NSSAs are excluded).
This object is persistent and when written
the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile
storage.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfExtLsdbLimit

description: An ospfLsdbApproachingOverflow trap signifies
that the number of LSAs in the router's
link state database has exceeded ninety percent of
ospfExtLsdbLimit.

event.Summary: Number of LSAs Exceeds 90% of ospfExtLsdbLimit - {$v2}

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfLsdbApproachingOverflow OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId a 127.0.0.1 OSPF-MIB::ospfExtLsdbLimit i 9999

description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the
router in the Autonomous System.
By convention, to ensure uniqueness, this
should default to the value of one of the
router's IP interface addresses.
This object is persistent and when written
the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId

description: The maximum number of non-default
AS-external LSAs entries that can be stored in the
link state database. If the value is -1, then
there is no limit.
When the number of non-default AS-external LSAs
in a router's link state database reaches
ospfExtLsdbLimit, the router enters
overflow state. The router never holds more than
ospfExtLsdbLimit non-default AS-external LSAs
in its database. OspfExtLsdbLimit MUST be set
identically in all routers attached to the OSPF
backbone and/or any regular OSPF area (i.e.
OSPF stub areas and NSSAs are excluded).
This object is persistent and when written
the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile
storage.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfExtLsdbLimit

description: An ospfIfStateChange trap signifies that there
has been a change in the state of a non-virtual
OSPF interface. This trap should be generated
when the interface state regresses (e.g., goes
from Dr to Down) or progresses to a terminal
state (i.e., Point-to-Point, DR Other, Dr, or
Backup).

Summary.eval: ($v3 == 0) ? 'ospfIfStateChange: InterfaceState - {$v4} and InterfaceIPAddress - {$v2}' : 'ospfIfStateChange: InterfaceState - {$v4} and NoIpAddress-InterfaceIfIndex - {$v3}'

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfIfStateChange OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId a 127.0.0.1 OSPF-MIB::ospfIfIpAddress a 127.0.0.1 OSPF-MIB::ospfAddressLessIf i 9999 OSPF-MIB::ospfIfState i 1

description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the
router in the Autonomous System.
By convention, to ensure uniqueness, this
should default to the value of one of the
router's IP interface addresses.
This object is persistent and when written
the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId

description: The IP address of this OSPF interface.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfIfIpAddress

description: For the purpose of easing the instancing of
addressed and addressless interfaces; this
variable takes the value 0 on interfaces with
IP addresses and the corresponding value of
ifIndex for interfaces having no IP address.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfAddressLessIf

description: The OSPF Interface State.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfIfState

description: An ospfNssaTranslatorStatusChange trap indicates that
there has been a change in the router's ability to
translate OSPF type-7 LSAs into OSPF type-5 LSAs.
This trap should be generated when the translator
status transitions from or to any defined status on
a per-area basis.

Summary.eval: ($v3 == 1) ? 'NSSA Border Router set to State - {Enabled} and  AreaID - {$v2}' : (($v3 == 2) ? 'NSSA Border Router is Translating Type-7 LSAs Into Type-5 of State - {Elected} and AreaID: {$v2}' : (($v3 == 3) ? 'NSSA Border Router is Not Translating Type-7 LSAs Into Type-5 of Stae - {Disabled} and AreaID - {$v2}' : 'NSSA Translator State - {Unknown} and AreaID - {$v2}'))

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfNssaTranslatorStatusChange OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId a 127.0.0.1 OSPF-MIB::ospfAreaId a 127.0.0.1 OSPF-MIB::ospfAreaNssaTranslatorState i 1

description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the
router in the Autonomous System.
By convention, to ensure uniqueness, this
should default to the value of one of the
router's IP interface addresses.
This object is persistent and when written
the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId

description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying an area.
Area ID 0.0.0.0 is used for the OSPF backbone.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfAreaId

description: Indicates if and how an NSSA border router is
performing NSSA translation of type-7 LSAs into type-5
LSAs. When this object is set to enabled, the NSSA Border
router's OspfAreaNssaExtTranslatorRole has been set to
always. When this object is set to elected, a candidate
NSSA Border router is Translating type-7 LSAs into type-5.
When this object is set to disabled, a candidate NSSA
border router is NOT translating type-7 LSAs into type-5.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfAreaNssaTranslatorState

description: An ospfRestartStatusChange trap signifies that
there has been a change in the graceful restart
state for the router. This trap should be
generated when the router restart status
changes.

event.Summary: OSPFRestartStatusChange: Change in graceful restart state to - {$v2}, due to last Attempt of graceful restart - {$v4}

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfRestartStatusChange OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId a 127.0.0.1 OSPF-MIB::ospfRestartStatus i 1 OSPF-MIB::ospfRestartInterval i 999 OSPF-MIB::ospfRestartExitReason i 1

description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the
router in the Autonomous System.
By convention, to ensure uniqueness, this
should default to the value of one of the
router's IP interface addresses.
This object is persistent and when written
the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId

description: Current status of OSPF graceful restart.
variables.name: OSPfF-MIB::ospfRestartStatus

description: Configured OSPF graceful restart timeout interval.
This object is persistent and when written
the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile
storage.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfRestartInterval

description: Describes the outcome of the last attempt at a
graceful restart. If the value is 'none', no restart
has yet been attempted. If the value is 'inProgress'
a restart attempt is currently underway.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfRestartExitReason

description: An ospfNbrRestartHelperStatusChange trap signifies that
there has been a change in the graceful restart
helper state for the neighbor. This trap should be
generated when the neighbor restart helper status
transitions for a neighbor.

Summary.eval: ($v3 == 0) ? 'ospfNbrRestartHelperStatusChange: RouterID - {$v1} Graceful Restart (Last Attempt State - {$v7}) Helper for the NeighborIpAddress - {$v2} is {$v5}' : 'ospfNbrRestartHelperStatusChange: RouterID - {$v1} Graceful Restart (Last Attempt State - {$v7}) Helper for the NeighborIpAddress - {$v2} is {$v5}, NoIpAddress-InterfaceIfIndex - {$v3}'

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfNbrRestartHelperStatusChange OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId a 127.0.0.1 OSPF-MIB::ospfNbrIpAddr a 127.0.0.1 OSPF-MIB::ospfNbrAddressLessIndex i 9999 OSPF-MIB::ospfNbrRtrId a 127.0.0.1 OSPF-MIB::ospfNbrRestartHelperStatus i 1 OSPF-MIB::ospfNbrRestartHelperAge u 9999 OSPF-MIB::ospfNbrRestartHelperExitReason i 1

description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the
router in the Autonomous System.
By convention, to ensure uniqueness, this
should default to the value of one of the
router's IP interface addresses.
This object is persistent and when written
the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId

description: The IP address this neighbor is using in its
IP source address. Note that, on addressless
links, this will not be 0.0.0.0 but the
address of another of the neighbor's interfaces.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfNbrIpAddr

description: On an interface having an IP address, zero.
On addressless interfaces, the corresponding
value of ifIndex in the Internet Standard MIB.
On row creation, this can be derived from the
instance.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfNbrAddressLessIndex

description: A 32-bit integer (represented as a type
IpAddress) uniquely identifying the neighboring
router in the Autonomous System.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfNbrRtrId

description: Indicates whether the router is acting
as a graceful restart helper for the neighbor.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfNbrRestartHelperStatus

description: Remaining time in current OSPF graceful restart
interval, if the router is acting as a restart
helper for the neighbor.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfNbrRestartHelperAge

description: Describes the outcome of the last attempt at acting
as a graceful restart helper for the neighbor.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfNbrRestartHelperExitReason

description: An ospfVirtNbrRestartHelperStatusChange trap signifies
that there has been a change in the graceful restart
helper state for the virtual neighbor. This trap should
be generated when the virtual neighbor restart helper
status transitions for a virtual neighbor.

event.Summary: ospfVirtNbrRestartHelperStatusChange: Virtual-RouterID - {$v1} Graceful Restart (Last Attempt State - {$v6}) Helper for the VirtualNeighborRouterID - {$v3} is {$v4} and TransitAreaID- {$v2}

objects.test: $SNMPTRAPCMD OSPF-TRAP-MIB::ospfVirtNbrRestartHelperStatusChange OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId a 127.0.0.1 OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtNbrArea a 127.0.0.1 OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtNbrRtrId a 127.0.0.1 OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtNbrRestartHelperStatus i 1 OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtNbrRestartHelperAge u 9999 OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtNbrRestartHelperExitReason i 1

description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the
router in the Autonomous System.
By convention, to ensure uniqueness, this
should default to the value of one of the
router's IP interface addresses.
This object is persistent and when written
the entity SHOULD save the change to non-volatile storage.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfRouterId

description: The Transit Area Identifier.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtNbrArea

description: A 32-bit integer uniquely identifying the
neighboring router in the Autonomous System.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtNbrRtrId

description: Indicates whether the router is acting
as a graceful restart helper for the neighbor.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtNbrRestartHelperStatus

description: Remaining time in current OSPF graceful restart
interval, if the router is acting as a restart
helper for the neighbor.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtNbrRestartHelperAge

description: Describes the outcome of the last attempt at acting
as a graceful restart helper for the neighbor.
variables.name: OSPF-MIB::ospfVirtNbrRestartHelperExitReason
